etymologies: Old English eliotropus (originally applied to various plants whose flowers turn towards the sun), via Latin from Greek hēliotropion ‘plant turning its flowers to the sun’, from hēlios ‘sun’ + trepein ‘to turn’. The spelling was influenced by French héliotrope

definitions: a plant of the borage family, cultivated for its fragrant purple or blue flowers which are used in perfume.
shortDefinitions: plant of borage family, cultivated for its fragrant purple or blue flowers which are used in perfume

definitions: a light purple color, similar to that typical of heliotrope flowers.
shortDefinitions: light purple colour, similar to that of heliotrope flowers
